et: Middle English {it}progenitour,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}prōgenitor{/it} "individual from whom a person or family is descended, ancestor," agentive derivative of {it}prōgignere{/it} "to produce as offspring, bring into being, give rise to" (from {it}prō-{/it} {et_link|pro-:2|pro-:2} + {it}gignere{/it} "to bring into being, beget, give birth to"), after {it}genitor{/it} "father, parent, originator," going back to Indo-European {it}*ǵenh{inf}1{/inf}-{/it} "engender, beget" + {it}*-tor/*-tōr,{/it} agent suffix, from which also Greek {it}genétōr{/it} "father, begetter, ancestor," Sanskrit {it}janitar-, janitá{/it} "father, progenitor" {ma}{mat|kin:1|}{/ma}

Alternatively {it}genitor{/it} has been explained as a new formation based on {it}genitus,{/it} past participle of {it}gignere.{/it} The older and still somewhat more attractive view sees {it}genitus{/it} as the new formation, based on the perfect {it}genuī{/it} or on {it}genitor{/it} itself, after the connection with the original verbal adjective ({it}g{/it}){it}nātus{/it} (going back to zero-grade {it}*ǵn̥h{inf}1{/inf}-to-{/it}) became weakened.
shortdef: an ancestor in the direct line : forefather
